title: Prince William reveals how he has spent time with his kids | Royal | News
body_text:
Prince William reveals how he has spent time with George, Charlotte and Louis this week
Prince William has revealed how his children have been spending their half term this week.
Prince William revealed he has been watching sports during Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis's half term this week.
The young trio - all students at Lambrook School in Berkshire - are currently enjoying a break from school like many children across the country.
According to the official website for their school, George, Charlotte and Louis will be returning to school on Monday, November 4.
Taking to X, William celebrated that Aston Villa - his football team - had become the first team to win three games in the Champions League this season. The royal, 42, tweeted: "Of course I was watching, @Ally_McCoist9."
He tagged sports commentator Ally McCoist – who had given William a shout out during the match – and signed it with a "W" and a clenched arm muscle emoji.

Much like his dad, George, 11, has also become a Villa fan and would surely have been watching the match - potentially along with his two younger siblings.
His sister Princess Charlotte, nine, is also said to be a fan of sports and joined her dad to cheer on England's Lionesses during the 2024 Women's World Cup.
Ally recently received an OBE from Prince William and shared a picture with fans. Alongside the photo, he wrote: "Such a proud moment for myself and my family, I am humbled to be receiving my OBE from Prince William at Windsor Castle today.
"Thank you for all the support and messages. It means so much. Did we speak about @AVFCOfficial?? That’s between the Prince and I."
William was among the spectators at the team's grounds Villa Park alongside his and wife Kate's close friend, Thomas van Straubenzee, earlier this month. He was present to watch the first match between Villa and German giants Bayern, which Villa won 1-0 in a repeat of their 1982 European Cup final win.
